title: How to write a leading tone in the key of F-sharp minor - Quora

response.answer_text: You find the seventh degree of the natural minor scale and then raise it by a half-step. This pitch should sit one half-step below the tonic tone, so you can also think of it that way. The leading tone is already present (raised) in the melodic and harmonic minors, and in the major as well. Correct musical spelling is important for a number of reasons, no matter how bonkers it may seem to you at first; if the letter-name of the leading tone is the one that comes just before the letter-name of the tonic in the musical alphabet, then you’re on the right track. In most keys, an accidental will also need to be applied. In F-sharp minor (or major), the leading tone is E-sharp (not F natural—heavens, no). And in G-sharp minor (or major), the leading tone is F-double-sharp, not G natural.

Use E sharp in ALL cases where it functions as a leading tone in F sharp minor, even if you are only temporarily in F sharp minor. It gives the performer important information as to fingering and tuning. Don’t respell it unless the WHOLE chord is respelled (which it probably won’t be in this case.)
